title: [DOC] User guide
body:
contributors: @fkiraly, @lynnssi, @mloning

## Purpose of the user guide
In addition to our API reference, we want to create a user guide. The API reference serves as a technical software reference. The user guide should serve as a scientific reference. In the user guide, we want to give an overview of sktime, including the 
* taxonomy of learning tasks, 
* how they are related and the concept of reduction, 
* sktime's package structure, 
* an overview of task-specific submodules (classification, forecasting, etc),
* guidance/explanations of algorithms 

## How to contribute

* All user guide pages are in the `sktime/docs/source/user_guide/` folder, the overview page is `sktime/docs/source/user_guide.rst`
* You can edit existing pages or create new ones and link them in the overview page
* You can use restructured text (`.rst`) format or Jupyter notebooks

## Contents 

### Introduction
"Introduction to SKTIME, motivation, structure, high-level how to use"

* assumption about users: basic understanding of scikit-learn/tabular setting
* introductory example showing that there are multiple learning tasks in a time series context
* "there are many dedicated time series algorithms, you don't have to use deep learning to solve time series problems"

### Overview of time series learning tasks

* task diagnosis (flow diagram): "how to diagnose which task you are dealing with" - include tasks that we currently do not support, see #210
* reduction: how to adapt an algorithm for one task to solve another related task (diagram of reduction relations between learning tasks/algorithms)
* three aspects of task specification: 1) generative setting, 2) learning, 3) evaluation

### Time series transformations
* many time series specific algorithms are compositions of prior transformations and tabular algorithms from scikit-learn
* series-to-series, series-to-primitive 
* variations: fitted to single series or across independent instances
* compositor: apply transforms locally (e.g. on interval) or globally over entire time series

### Time series classification
"predicting a categorical target variable from time series"
* why do we distinguish between time series and tabular regression? 
* example (data generators)
* specifying the task:
    * assumed generative settings (data format: univariate, multivariate, panel data; statistical dependency structure)
    * learning (input/output of algorithm type)
    * evaluation
* variations (univariate, multivariate, online learning)
* algorithm taxonomy: see #355 
    * dictionary-based 
    * frequency-based (e.g. RISE)
    * interval-based (e.g. TSF)
    * shapelet-based
    * distance-based
    * deep-learning
* guidance on algorithm choice 

### Time series regression
"predicting a continuous target variables from time series"
* why do we distinguish between time series and tabular regression? 
* example
* assumed generative settings (data format: univariate, multivariate, panel data; statistical dependency structure)
* learning (input/output of algorithm type)
* evaluation

### Forecasting
"temporal forward prediction"
* example
* assumed generative settings (data format: univariate, multivariate, panel data; statistical dependency structure)

### Time series annotation
"annotating time points"
e.g. anomaly detection/outlier detection
